awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Conceptual Learning of Calculus through the 3D Serious Game Series: Variant
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to significantly reduce Calculus failure rates.  Success in Calculus is a prediction of persistence in STEM degree programs; but many students do not successfully complete Calculus courses. This reduces graduation rates and restricts hiring into STEM careers. Ultimately, this barrier impacts the Presidents call for one million more STEM graduates. When playing Variant, a 3D educational game, students are drawn into an interactive world and gameplay.  The game allows students to develop a conceptual understanding of Calculus without reliance on definitions, terminology, formulas, and calculations, via a heuristic, experiential learning environment. Variant assists learners in grasping core concepts in Calculus, which ultimately leads to higher persistence, retention, and graduation rates in STEM degrees. 

The proposed project is focused on developing the Variant games series for higher education and secondary (grades 9-12) Calculus. Unlike current games and homework platforms that rely on repetitive drills or address lower level mathematical concepts, Variant presents complex experiential explorations. Variant differentiates itself from other games in terms of educational rigor and its 3D environment, that allows students to be more engaged and immersed when learning Calculus content. A stealth assessment will be integrated within the game system to provide real-time feedback and inform development of the instructor portal. Without interrupting the game experience, the stealth assessment measures a players knowledge gain and validates gameplay as a measure of achievement of the student learning objectives.

por.por_cntn:
Summary
Within the NSF SBIR Phase I grant, the Triseum team set out to create an interactive calculus experience that would not only engage and excite students, but also motivate them to master calculus concepts. Triseum's research and development resulted in the prototype of Variant: Gamelets, in which students solve a variety of challenges and puzzles to develop a qualitative understanding of the content. Variant: Gamelets is part of Triseum's Variant calculus game series, which also includes Variant: Limits.

Gameplay within Variant: Gamelets does not rely on players memorizing terms, formulas or algorithms. Rather, it inspires active learning as players apply their knowledge. Ultimately, three Gamelets were created as part of the Phase I grant: 1) Graphing, 2) Energy, and 3) Refining. Each Gamelet has been created with different game mechanics designed to address specific concepts and student learning objectives:

  • Graphing provides students the ability to explore graphical representations of first and second derivatives, extrema and approximation. Students also are able to master the application of critical points when graphing functions, first derivatives and second derivates.
  • Energy encourages students to visualize the relationships between the motion of an object and its derivatives. The 3D environment of Energy facilitates gameplay around the application of velocity, applied minimums and maximums, and related rates.
  • Refining allows students to derive mathematical functions that visualize derivative rules, chain rules, and applications of deeper derivatives. Students can experiment with a variety of methods as they learn the proper steps to solve the mathematical problem.

The game mechanics within Variant: Gamelets, when paired with Variant: Limits, addresses approximately 30% of the calculus sequence over the course of the semester. Developing vastly different game mechanics enabled Triseum to conduct playtests and efficacy research, ensuring each educational outcome was being appropriately addressed. The results of the Variant: Gamelets – Graphing research playtest revealed that students' knowledge increased with more than one hour of gameplay (compared from pre- to post-assessment). Students commented that Variant: Gamelets – Graphing was fun and engaging, while it also increased their knowledge and helped them understand the concepts covered within the game.

 

Impact
Triseum’s purpose and goal with the Variant series align with the NSF mission to capitalize on new concepts in science and engineering and provide global leadership in advancing research and education. While the body of evidence for game-based learning has grown over time, Variant is the first of its kind to incorporate entertainment quality graphics, narrative and game design, immersing students into gameplay and content. Variant provides a new method to engage students of all backgrounds in calculus. As seen with previous research in Fall 2017 with ARTé: Mecenas and Fall 2018 with Variant: Limits, both games improved knowledge efficacy regardless of gender, ethnicity or previous gameplay experience.

Variant assists learners in grasping core concepts in calculus, which can ultimately lead to higher exam scores, course grades, retention and graduation rates in STEM degrees. Variant also can be used to promote innovative educational pedagogies and teaching methodologies to transform math and calculus instruction.
